title: Writs under Article 32 and 226 of the Indian Constitution

information.title: Constitutional Provisions
information.description: Article 32 empowers the Supreme Court to issue writs for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights. Article 226 gives similar powers to High Courts, but for a broader range of purposes including the enforcement of legal rights.

information.title: Types of Writs
information.description: There are five types of writs: Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto. Each serves a specific purpose in protecting rights and ensuring lawful governance.

information.title: Habeas Corpus
information.description: This writ is used to produce a person who has been detained, before the court and to release him if the detention is found to be illegal.

information.title: Mandamus
information.description: It is issued to compel a public official or a public body to perform their legal duty.

information.title: Prohibition
information.description: This writ is issued to prohibit a lower court or tribunal from proceeding with a case which it has no jurisdiction to entertain.

information.title: Certiorari
information.description: It is issued to quash the order already passed by an inferior court, tribunal or quasi-judicial authority.

information.title: Quo Warranto
information.description: This writ is issued to inquire into the legality of claim of a person to a public office.

quizQuestions.question: Which Article empowers the Supreme Court to issue writs for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights?
How many types of writs are there under the Indian Constitution?
Which writ is used to produce a detained person before the court?
Which writ is issued to compel a public official to perform their legal duty?
What is the purpose of the writ of Quo Warranto?
options: To inquire into the legality of claim of a person to a public office
To release an illegally detained person
To compel performance of public duty
To quash the order of a lower court
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: To inquire into the legality of claim of a person to a public office
